metadata.synopsis: Default dialogue when speaking to Wyll during exploration.

5.speaker: Wyll
5.text: I can't use that when I'm in battle.

30.speaker: Wyll
30.text: Seek out the drider. Crush it like the vermin it is, and let the way to Moonrise open.
30.context: NodeContext: Not too dramatic or vehement.

101.speaker: Wyll
101.text: We can't let the Absolute taint my father's mind.

384.speaker: Wyll
384.text: And we must find this captured devil. Two missions. One destination.

56.speaker: Wyll
56.text: I'm all chatted out, I'm afraid - though I may have a word with the chief.

63.speaker: Wyll
63.text: Now's not the time. I need a breather.

69.speaker: Wyll
69.text: Back to camp. The sooner the better.

80.speaker: Wyll
80.text: I can't use this at the moment.

86.speaker: Wyll
86.text: I'm sorry. I might have come on a little strong with the dance invitation.

369.speaker: Wyll
369.text: I was imagining my younger days, prancing about without a care in the world.

50.speaker: Wyll
50.text: We may never be dance partners. But we have fellowship, and I wouldn't trade that for all the gold in the Gate Counting House.

130.speaker: Wyll
130.text: Well - that's enough sentiment for one day. What did you need?

111.speaker: Wyll
111.text: Gods be damned. With that parasite in his brain, father could wreak untold havoc in the Absolute's name.

152.speaker: Wyll
152.text: Should Baldur's Gate fall to the Absolute, every one of the Coast's cities will be ripe for the plucking.

99.speaker: Wyll
99.text: We're not just fighting for our cure. We're fighting for my father, we're fighting for the Gate, we're fighting for all of Faerûn.

117.speaker: Wyll
117.text: The Astral Plane. Beautiful, otherworldly - and ever-so-slightly unnerving.

129.speaker: Wyll
129.text: The Blade of Frontiers, at your calling.

290.speaker: Player
290.text: Wyll, you had an idea about the insight trial, yes?

314.speaker: Wyll
314.context: NodeContext: Wyll is giving an interpretaion of a puzzle solution based on some books you read.

245.speaker: Wyll
245.text: Suelto's Ethic of War would lead to endless conflict. No city could survive it.
245.context: NodeContext: Wyll is giving an interpretaion of a puzzle solution based on some books you read.

274.speaker: Wyll
274.text: Suelto is the one you should strike.
274.context: NodeContext: Wyll is giving an interpretaion of a puzzle solution based on some books you read.

0.speaker: Player
0.text: Your father is gone. I saw his corpse in the Iron Throne.
0.context: NodeContext: Reacting to his father's death

200.speaker: Player
200.text: I saw your father's corpse in the Iron Throne.

232.speaker: Player
232.text: That letter... your father is gone, Wyll. He went down with the Iron Throne.

334.speaker: Player
334.text: That letter... your father is gone, Wyll. He went down with the Iron Throne.

205.speaker: Player
205.text: That letter... your father went down with the Iron Throne. But maybe Mizora can still help.

335.speaker: Player
335.text: Reunited with your father. How does it feel?

172.speaker: Player
172.text: Ravengard's still infected. We can rescue him, but we can't cure him.

318.speaker: Player
318.text: Baldur's Gate has barred outsiders. That was quite a scene at the southern checkpoint.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: Could it be true? Duke Stelmane allied with the Emperor?

323.speaker: Player
323.text: Did you know Stelmane very well, back in the day?

216.speaker: Player
216.text: Stelmane's been murdered. Did you know her at all?

83.speaker: Player
83.text: It seems Grand Duke Stelmane's been murdered. Did you know her at all?

225.speaker: Player
225.text: We're nearing the city. Are you excited to return? Reluctant? A little of both?

178.speaker: Player
178.text: Why didn't you tell me you are the son of a duke? His tadpoling was a hell of a way to find out.

187.speaker: Wyll
187.text: I know. I should've told you sooner.
187.context: NodeContext: Slightly contrite but only very subtly so. Still strong and not too dramatic.

46.speaker: Wyll
46.text: I am a man of two faces.
46.context: NodeContext: Slightly contrite but only very subtly so. Still strong and not too dramatic.

164.speaker: Wyll
164.text: I am the Blade of Frontiers. A man hunting the fiends who prey on the weak and claw at the Coast.
164.context: NodeContext: Slightly contrite but only very subtly so. Still strong and not too dramatic.

243.speaker: Wyll
243.text: And I am Wyll Ravengard. A memory of a memory. A man who belongs to the past.
243.context: NodeContext: Slightly contrite but only very subtly so. Still strong and not too dramatic.

365.speaker: Wyll
365.text: I wanted you to know the Blade, not the shadow he left behind.
365.context: NodeContext: Slightly contrite but only very subtly so. Still strong and not too dramatic.

176.speaker: Player
176.text: The Absolute's cult has Ravengard. Where will they take him?

208.speaker: Wyll
208.text: Wyrm's Rock fortress. All travellers to Baldur's Gate flow through it.
208.context: NodeContext: In normal tone, not angry

92.speaker: Wyll
92.text: It serves as headquarters for the Flaming Fist - and their commander: my father.
92.context: NodeContext: In normal tone, not angry

256.speaker: Wyll
256.text: The Absolute's army's on the march. Gods forbid a tadpoled Grand Duke throw open the gates for them.

70.speaker: Player
70.text: What do you know about Gortash and Orin?

93.speaker: Wyll
93.text: Orin, I'd never heard tell of. But Gortash I know. Or know of, more precisely. A self-styled 'strategic advisor' to Baldur's Gate's peers.

217.speaker: Wyll
217.text: A bit player with dreams of a leading role, the way father told it. He had no use for Gortash, and even less for his 'advice'.

38.speaker: Wyll
38.text: I don't remember much beyond that. But where these 'Chosen' are concerned, I have a suspicion we're about to know more than we'd like.

271.speaker: Player
271.text: You must've been furious at your father for throwing you out of the city.

291.speaker: Player
291.text: Any idea where we'll find Duke Ravengard, now that we've reached Moonrise?

125.speaker: Wyll
125.text: Not in a mere prison cell, certainly. My guess? Thorm will have confined him in the bowels of the tower.

295.speaker: Wyll
295.text: The deeper we dig, the closer we get.

253.speaker: Player
253.text: About your battle with the dragon cultists - is that how you lost your eye?

169.speaker: Player
169.text: I don't understand. Why would Mizora help you save Baldur's Gate?

19.speaker: Player
19.text: Your father can't have been happy to find you were pacted.

250.speaker: Player
250.text: I want you to finish your story about the Cult of the Dragon - and your pact.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: Mizora said you can say what led to your pact and exile. It's time I know the whole truth.

212.speaker: Player
212.text: You've talked about your father, but not your mother. Why's that?

209.speaker: Wyll
209.text: Because there's nothing to tell. She died when I was born.

68.speaker: Wyll
68.text: As a boy, my bond with father was too deep to miss the mother I never had.

13.speaker: Wyll
13.text: Now, well - I'd be lying if I said I'd never thought about my mother. What life would've been like if she'd lived.

362.speaker: Wyll
362.text: Maybe I'd be living in the city. Maybe I'd never have been forced into this cursed pact.

108.speaker: Wyll
108.text: But there's no use lingering on 'maybes'. My mind is on the stories of today and tomorrow, not those of yesterday.

18.speaker: Player
18.text: The cultists have taken your father to Moonrise Towers. Florrick's confirmed it.

304.speaker: Player
304.text: You said you had something important to talk about. What is it?

327.speaker: Player
327.text: What was it like, being the son of a Grand Duke?

194.speaker: Player
194.text: Ravengard is your father. Why didn't you tell me?

15.speaker: Player
15.text: Mizora wants us to rescue a devil from Moonrise. Is this a common sort of request?

265.speaker: Player
265.text: Raphael is making a bid for Mol's loyalty. What do you make of it?

196.speaker: Player
196.text: Who set you on my tail, mister 'Blade'?

215.speaker: Player
215.text: What do you make of Raphael?

54.speaker: Player
54.text: How does the Blade of Frontiers end up chasing a devil in the Hells?

17.speaker: Player
17.text: Tell me, Wyll: How did you come to be the Blade of Frontiers?

293.speaker: Player
293.text: I've noticed your stone eye. Did you lose it in battle?

352.speaker: Player
352.text: I don't suppose you've come across an expert healer in your travels.

42.speaker: Wyll
42.text: I've come to know a fair few village clerics, but none with the skill to pull these worms from our heads.

154.speaker: Wyll
154.text: From what I understand, there's a healer called Nettie in the grove. Perhaps she's got the talent.

82.speaker: Wyll
82.text: We should pay her a visit.

149.speaker: Wyll
149.text: Otherwise, I'd bet my last coin that the Open Hand Temple in Baldur's Gate could help - though a fat lot of good that does us now.

287.speaker: Player
287.text: You were alarmed to hear the Grand Duke was trapped. Or am I mistaken?

228.speaker: Wyll
228.text: You're not mistaken. Ravengard is - an important figure to the city. Should he die...

158.speaker: Wyll
158.text: I won't entertain the notion. We must save him - it's as simple as that.

183.speaker: Player
183.text: How does it feel to be a devil?

8.speaker: Player
8.text: You should get out of this pact.

303.speaker: Player
303.text: How in the Hells did you get involved with Mizora?

4.speaker: Player
4.text: About Kagha. What do you think of her?

329.speaker: Player
329.text: What do you think of the illithid potential the dream visitor spoke of?

146.speaker: Player
146.text: The Emperor promises incredible powers - if we're willing to pursue them.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: How would you feel about involving someone else in our relationship?

371.speaker: Wyll
371.text: Halsin, you mean. I've seen the longing in your eyes. You've looked at me like that before, too.

107.speaker: Wyll
107.text: I might share a bowl of venison stew with Halsin, but never a partner in dance.

2.speaker: Wyll
2.text: Choose Halsin, and our story may still be an epic - but it won't be a romance.

87.speaker: Player
87.text: I want to be with you, no question.

230.speaker: Wyll
230.text: It feels good to hear it. Almost as good as the touch of your hand and the glow of your smile.

359.speaker: Wyll
359.text: You shine brighter than diamond and strike harder than steel. A rare treasure. Don't you ever forget it.

174.speaker: Player
174.text: Yes - it's over between us. I'd like to be with Halsin.

113.speaker: Wyll
113.text: I - I understand. All the more fool am I for pressing my fortunes.

153.speaker: Wyll
153.text: Thank you. For the dance, for your understanding, and making a fantasy become reality - even if just for a moment.

380.speaker: Wyll
380.text: Gifts burned into my memories. I wouldn't give them up for the world.

255.speaker: Player
255.text: I always thought we could have been more than just allies. And you?

181.speaker: Wyll
181.text: I thought of the possibility more than once, if you must know.

316.speaker: Wyll
316.text: You lent an ear when I most needed one. And when I shared my fears, you didn't judge me.

381.speaker: Wyll
381.text: I even had a special night planned, just you and me. But priorities tend to drift in times as tough as these.

28.speaker: Wyll
28.text: But it was nice thinking about what might have been, if fate had chosen differently.

43.speaker: Wyll
43.text: But no use dwelling on might-have-beens. I am proud to call you ally. Prouder still to call you friend.

81.speaker: Wyll
81.text: But no use dwelling on might-have-beens. I am proud to call you ally. I hope you can say the same.

377.speaker: Player
377.text: I thought you should know - I've partnered with Lae'zel.

201.speaker: Player
201.text: I thought you should know - I've partnered with Gale.

341.speaker: Player
341.text: I thought you should know - I've partnered with Karlach.

309.speaker: Player
309.text: I thought you should know - I've partnered with Astarion.

264.speaker: Player
264.text: I thought you should know - I've partnered with Shadowheart.

338.speaker: Player
338.text: I don't have eyes for Astarion anymore - only for you.

66.speaker: Player
66.text: I don't have eyes for Karlach anymore - only for you.

280.speaker: Player
280.text: I don't have eyes for Lae'zel anymore - only for you.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: I don't have eyes for Gale anymore - only for you.

389.speaker: Wyll
389.text: Indeed? My heart is joyed to hear it, but... why?

179.speaker: Player
179.text: I don't have eyes for Shadowheart anymore - only for you.

385.speaker: Player
385.text: I've got no memory of my past. Could the parasite have done that?

73.speaker: Wyll
73.text: Then again, we're talking about tadpoles inserted into our brains by rubber-skinned tentacle monsters. There's nothing usual about it.

260.speaker: Wyll
260.text: All the more reason to stick close, I think you'll agree.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: I've got this... bloodthirst. An urge to destroy, maim, kill.

234.speaker: Wyll
234.text: Anger, I understand. We've been preyed on by illithids, suffered insertion of a mind-bending worm.

59.speaker: Wyll
59.text: Bloodthirst is another matter. But perhaps not too big of one, if it's a devil or demon's flesh you're wanting to tear.

382.speaker: Player
382.text: I didn't kill Alfira, I swear it.

22.speaker: Wyll
22.text: Is that so? Maybe that's fear of false accusation I hear in your voice. Or maybe it's guilt.

37.speaker: Wyll
37.text: Whichever is true, I will not stand for more innocent blood being shed in our camp.

282.speaker: Player
282.text: I could have killed you when I was possessed. How do I know I won't try again?

364.speaker: Wyll
364.text: But you are stronger than the hunger. You can resist, you will resist. I'm sure of it.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: Bow before me, for I have become the Slayer!

328.speaker: Wyll
328.text: Hells. Is this really what you've become - the kind of monster I once vowed to slay?

376.speaker: Wyll
376.text: Don't bother answering - I already know.

91.speaker: Player
91.text: Isobel is no more. Glory to the darkness left in her absence!

173.speaker: Wyll
173.text: Gods - you left Last Light for the shadows to feed on. You should be shamed for your villainy, not extolled for it.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: I am born of the Lord of Murder. I am a Bhaalspawn.

144.speaker: Wyll
144.text: Listen to me. I knew another like you - Gorion's Ward, one of Baldur's Gate's great heroes. Bhaal's blood ran through their veins too.

252.speaker: Wyll
252.text: They burned away their own darkness with their own inner light. They chose courage, they chose honour - and so can you.

286.speaker: Player
286.text: I have conquered my urges. The bloodlust has faded.

120.speaker: Wyll
120.text: I'm so glad to hear it. If I had a bottle of Dragondew, I'd open it in your honour.

227.speaker: Player
227.text: I am death, I am murder. I am the Chosen of Bhaal!

45.speaker: Wyll
45.text: By the gone gods. It isn't the blood you've spilled or the lives you've snuffed out that horrify me most.

248.speaker: Wyll
248.text: It's the pride you take in it, as if you've done all sixteen planes a great favour.

77.speaker: Wyll
77.text: When the Absolute falls, I wager our alliance falls with it.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: Wyll has no idea that you're a vampire spawn. Consider sharing.
9.context: InternalNodeContext: Avatar Astarion has the option to tell his companion that he's a vampire spawn.

60.speaker: Player
60.text: Consider telling Wyll of your affinity with Shar.

112.speaker: Narrator
112.text: *Wyll thinks highly of you. Perhaps he won't judge you too harshly.*

211.speaker: Narrator
211.text: *Wyll considers you an ally - but not quite a good friend. It's hard to know how he'd respond.*

333.speaker: Narrator
333.text: *Wyll may be fond of the frontiers, but hardly of you. Maybe it's best to keep your Sharran nature to yourself.*

3.speaker: Player
3.text: Tell Wyll you worship the Lady of Loss.

12.speaker: Player
12.text: Tell Wyll you worship the Lady of Loss.

127.speaker: Player
127.text: Tell Wyll you worship the Lady of Loss.

350.speaker: Wyll
350.text: So you're one of Shar's faithful. I've known only a few - callous souls, every one of them.

278.speaker: Wyll
278.text: But you, Shadowheart - your darkness is gilded in silver. Keep your trust in me, and I'll keep mine in you.

29.speaker: Wyll
29.text: So it's the Dark Lady who's shadowed your heart, is it? I might have guessed.

133.speaker: Wyll
133.text: I've known only a few Sharrans - callous souls, every one of them.

198.speaker: Wyll
198.text: I appreciate the honesty, at least. With Shar's dagger so near, I'll know to guard my back.

16.speaker: Player
16.text: Keep your thoughts on the matter to yourself.

251.speaker: Player
251.text: Tell Wyll the story of your orb. Leave nothing out.

322.speaker: Wyll
322.text: Ah - you drank of the goblet of godhood. Not even a dwarf could distil a liquor more addictive.

1.speaker: Wyll
1.text: And now you carry doom itself within you as penance. My father would lecture you on the perils of power-lust -

159.speaker: Wyll
159.text: - but that's not a lesson that needs repeating, I wager.

272.speaker: Player
272.text: I'd like to talk about Elminster's visit.

210.speaker: Wyll
210.text: A shame my first brush with the famed Elminster couldn't be a tad more... optimistic.

374.speaker: Player
374.text: I'd like to talk about Elminster's visit.

36.speaker: Wyll
36.text: Quite an explosive secret to keep to yourself, Gale.

368.speaker: Wyll
368.text: Listen, Gale - I might invoke the Triad from time to time, appeal to Helm. But I'm no man of faith. Not like you.

118.speaker: Wyll
118.text: I don't know what drives a man to consider his own death, among countless others, to be an appropriate exchange for his goddess' forgiveness.

150.speaker: Wyll
150.text: To me, it all sounds like nonsense.

313.speaker: Wyll
313.text: The faith that matters is that which you hold in yourself, in the ones that most matter to you.

370.speaker: Wyll
370.text: Big bomb be damned, you've got everything you need to defeat the Absolute already: Talent, nerve, and powerful allies at your side.

281.speaker: Player
281.text: I'd like you to wait in the camp for now.

27.speaker: Wyll
27.text: Are you sure? The Blade stands at the ready.

324.speaker: Player
324.text: On second thought, I'd rather you stay with me.

267.speaker: Wyll
267.text: An excellent choice, if I say so myself.

319.speaker: Player
319.text: I'm sure. I'll find you in camp.

98.speaker: Player
98.text: Remain here. I'll come for you if I need to.

40.speaker: Wyll
40.text: And just when things were warming up.

356.speaker: Player
356.text: Go to camp and wait for me there.

346.speaker: Player
346.text: I'd like you to join me.

132.speaker: Wyll
132.text: Time's been stilled in this place. Peaceful - and disquieting, too. We should return to the crèche when we're able.

134.speaker: Wyll
134.text: Welcome to the League of the Lone Eye, my friend.

142.speaker: Wyll
142.text: Not to minimise the pain of Volo's poking and prodding, but I promise: you'll be used to the prosthesis in no time.

137.speaker: Wyll
137.text: Besides, I find it gives one an air of mystique. No one's more intriguing than an adventurer with one eye.

147.speaker: Wyll
147.text: Father will be waiting in camp. It's about time we talked.

157.speaker: Wyll
157.text: There's something I need to say, something important. Can you spare a moment?

138.speaker: Wyll
138.text: All right. But not too much later - I need to clear the air between us.

166.speaker: Wyll
166.text: The goblins still infest the roads. As long as their leaders live, Zevlor's people are trapped.

170.speaker: Wyll
170.text: By Balduran's helm, I wish we could have danced forever.

197.speaker: Wyll
197.text: Since we don't have forever, I wager the memory will have to do.

326.speaker: Player
326.text: There will be more dances to come, more memories to make. I promise.

285.speaker: Wyll
285.text: Indeed? I - I shiver just thinking about it. That day can't come soon enough.

367.speaker: Player
367.text: An unforgettable evening. I'll always cherish it.

283.speaker: Wyll
283.text: Me too. And once we've cured these infections of ours, I hope we'll share more nights just like it.

218.speaker: Player
218.text: It was nice to forget about our troubles for a while.

202.speaker: Wyll
202.text: Heh. And then like roaches, the troubles all came crawling back.

247.speaker: Wyll
247.text: Ah, well. I guess that's my cue to change the subject.

203.speaker: Wyll
203.text: Since the party, I've had a spring in my step. And I've got you to thank.

145.speaker: Player
145.text: I enjoyed myself, too. The kiss in particular.

75.speaker: Wyll
75.text: Unforgettable, I'd say. The right time, the right place - and the right person.

330.speaker: Wyll
330.text: Oh goodness, my cheeks've gone warm. Am I blushing? I must be blushing.

67.speaker: Player
67.text: It was a lovely evening. I hope we can share even more.

116.speaker: Wyll
116.text: I'm sure we will. And when the time comes, I've got something in mind.

39.speaker: Wyll
39.text: Now now, no prodding. You don't want to spoil the surprise. But I'll say this:

254.speaker: Wyll
254.text: Oh, that smile - it could light up a room. Hells, it could light up the entire Bay of Balduran.

100.speaker: Wyll
100.text: Ah, but I'm sure you didn't come by to bask in shameless flattery. To what do I owe the pleasure?

175.speaker: Wyll
175.text: Well, um - to what do I owe the pleasure?

237.speaker: Wyll
237.text: In my years as the Blade, I've witnessed countless cruelties, faced unimaginable evil.
237.context:
NodeContext: [Tom P] Pickup:
These lines sounded like they were recorded at different times and didn't flow well.

52.speaker: Wyll
52.text: But Thorm  - he is made of pure hate. The Sword Coast will rejoice when the bastard's fallen.
52.context:
NodeContext: [Tom P] Pickup:
These lines sounded like they were recorded at different times and didn't flow well.

262.speaker: Wyll
262.text: My father is somewhere in this tower. I won't leave him in Thorm's hands.
262.context:
NodeContext: [Tom P] Pickup:
These lines sounded like they were recorded at different times and didn't flow well.

182.speaker: Wyll
182.text: And lest we forget, we've a devil to rescue. Two missions, one destination.
182.context:
NodeContext: [Tom P] Pickup:
These lines sounded like they were recorded at different times and didn't flow well.

297.speaker: Narrator
297.text: *You catch a faint odour - one without any discernible source. Wet ash, dried mud, and a hint of sulphur.*

296.speaker: Narrator
296.text: *Mizora channelled the Hells' essence into you - you'll never be rid of their scent.*

305.speaker: Wyll
305.text: Our happily-ever-after wasn't to be, but I still treasure our alliance. Now come - we've plenty of work still ahead of us.

315.speaker: Wyll
315.text: I hope, I pray, that you'll show more care in the future.

310.speaker: Wyll
310.text: About what happened - we need to talk.

320.speaker: Wyll
320.text: Keep moving, keep fighting. No holding back.

321.speaker: Wyll
321.text: Please, we need to see to my father.

340.speaker: Narrator
340.text: *Your mind mingles with Wyll's, and he learns of Mizora's mission to Moonrise.*

151.speaker: Wyll
151.text: The more bullshit she pours, the more of it I'm forced to swallow.

357.speaker: Wyll
357.text: The more bullshit she pours, the more of it I'm forced to swallow.

360.speaker: Wyll
360.text: The shadows are cruel. It would take a miracle for Arabella's mother and father to survive them.

240.speaker: Wyll
240.text: Lucky for us, we've got a knack for miracles. Let's reunite the girl with her mother and father. She deserves that much.

363.speaker: Wyll
363.text: No use pretending anymore, is it? Duke Ravengard is my father - though I suppose I'm speaking the obvious.

268.speaker: Wyll
268.text: And yes, I should have told you sooner. But I am a man of two faces.

383.speaker: Wyll
383.text: Always good to talk, my friend.
